titleStmt.title: The Quakers Pedigree: or, a dialogue between a Quaker, and a Iesuit who at last become reconciled, as (holding in a great measure) the same principles; wherein is shown how the mystery of Quakerisme was first hatcht by the Jesuites: by what arts, and for what design it was set on foot in England; and by what means it hath been propagated since, and is still defended. With their contrivance for the carrying it on for the future.

The Quakers Pedigree: or, a dialogue between a Quaker, and a Iesuit who at last become reconciled, as (holding in a great measure) the same principles; wherein is shown how the mystery of Quakerisme was first hatcht by the Jesuites: by what arts, and for what design it was set on foot in England; and by what means it hath been propagated since, and is still defended. With their contrivance for the carrying it on for the future.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for Benjamin Harris, at the Stationers Arms in Swishins Alley, near the Royal Exchange,

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the Friends' House Library, London.
